{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2016}} {{Use Australian English|date=November 2016}} '''Justine Clark''' is an architectural editor, writer, speaker and researcher, based in [[Melbourne]], [[Australia]]. She is the editor of ''Parlour'', a former editor of ''[[Architecture Australia]]'', and co-author of ''Looking for the Local: Architecture and the New Zealand Modern''.
== Education == Born in [[New Zealand]], Clark completed her bachelor's degree with honours in architecture at the [[University of Auckland]] and her master's degree by research with distinction in architecture at [[Victoria University of Wellington]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Justine Clark|url = http://architectureau.com/contributors/Clark-Justine/|website = ArchitectureAU|accessdate = 2015-09-13}}</ref> She currently resides in Melbourne, Australia.
== Career == After completing her education, Clark was the 1998 National Library Research Fellow at the [[Alexander Turnbull Library]], which resulted in the publication of the book ''Looking for the Local: Architecture and the New Zealand Modern'', co-authored with Paul Walker, and accompanying exhibition.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Looking for the Local {{!}} Adam Art Gallery|url = http://www.adamartgallery.org.nz/past-exhibitions/looking-for-the-local/|website = www.adamartgallery.org.nz|accessdate = 2015-09-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Home straight, Meghan Nordeck|url = http://nzbooks.org.nz/1999/non-fiction/home-straight-meghan-nordeck/|accessdate = 2015-09-13}}</ref>
Clark was the editor of ''Architecture Australia'', the magazine of the [[Australian Institute of Architects]], from 2003 to 2011.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Justine Clark - Office of the Victorian Government Architect|url = http://www.ovga.vic.gov.au/victorian-design-review-panel/profile-page/15-profiles/26-justine-clark.html|website = www.ovga.vic.gov.au|accessdate = 2015-09-13|first = Kate|last = Mallyon|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151117021405/http://www.ovga.vic.gov.au/victorian-design-review-panel/profile-page/15-profiles/26-justine-clark.html|archivedate = 17 November 2015|df = dmy-all}}</ref> She was a collaborator on the [http://www.arc.gov.au/ Australia Research Council] (ARC) linkage grant funded project "Equity and Diversity in the Australian Architecture Profession: Women, Work, and Leadership", led by Dr [[Naomi Stead]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Equity and Diversity in the Australian Architecture Profession: Women, Work, and Leadership - Architecture Theory Criticism History - The University of Queensland, Australia|url = http://atch.architecture.uq.edu.au/equity-and-diversity-australian-architecture-profession-women-work-and-leadership|website = atch.architecture.uq.edu.au|accessdate = 2015-09-13}}</ref> Her involvement in this project lead to her position as founding editor of the online publication ''Parlour: Women, Equity, Architecture'', which began as a repository for the ARC research and is now an ongoing platform for the dissemination of research on gender, equity and architecture.
She has reviewed architecture for ''[[The Age]]'' newspaper and curates exhibitions. In addition to her work for ''Parlour'' she is a member the Office of the Victorian Government Architect's Design Review Panel<ref>{{Cite web|title = Justine Clark - Office of the Victorian Government Architect|url = http://www.ovga.vic.gov.au/victorian-design-review-panel/profile-page/15-profiles/26-justine-clark.html|website = www.ovga.vic.gov.au|accessdate = 2015-09-13|first = Kate|last = Mallyon|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151117021405/http://www.ovga.vic.gov.au/victorian-design-review-panel/profile-page/15-profiles/26-justine-clark.html|archivedate = 17 November 2015|df = dmy-all}}</ref> and the South Australian Office for Design and Architecture's Design Review Panel. Justine is an honorary research fellow at the Faculty of Architecture, Building and Planning at the [[University of Melbourne]].
== Selected publications == *{{cite book|first= Justine |last=Clark |first2=Paul |last2=Walker|title=Looking for the Local: Architecture and the New Zealand Modern|location=[[Wellington]]|publisher=[[Victoria University Press]]|year= 2000}}<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Reviews|url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/10331867.2000.10525144|journal = Fabrications|date = 2000-07-01|issn = 1033-1867|pages = 96–103|volume = 11|issue = 1|doi = 10.1080/10331867.2000.10525144|first = Ian|last = Lochhead|first2 = Miles|last2 = Lewis|first3 = Julia|last3 = Gatley}}</ref> *{{cite journal|first=Justine |last=Clark|title=Introduction to ''Architecture Australia'' Volume 100|journal= Architecture Australia|date= January 2011 |volume= 100 |number= 1|url= http://architectureau.com/articles/volume100/|accessdate=13 September 2015}} *{{cite journal|first=Justine |last=Clark|title=Morph and South, a Mixed Bag|journal= The Age|date= 2 November 2012|url=http://www.theage.com.au/entertainment/art-and-design/morph-and-south-a-mixed-bag-20121101-28mnh.html|accessdate=13 September 2015}} *{{cite encyclopedia|first= Justine |last=Clark |first2=Paul |last2=Walker|title=Interpretation, Intention and the Work of Architecture|encyclopedia=Semi-Detached: Writing, Representation and Criticism in Architecture|editor=Naomi Stead|publisher= URO Media|year= 2012}} *{{cite encyclopedia|first= Justine |last=Clark |first2=Paul |last2=Walker|title=Negotiating the Intention of the Work|encyclopedia=Ways to be Critical|volume =36|isbn= 978 90 77966 365 |year=2013|editor=Arjen Oosterman|publisher= Stichting Archis}} *{{cite journal|first=Justine |last=Clark|title=Where do all the Women Go?|journal= Architecture Australia|date=September 2014|url=http://architectureau.com/articles/where-do-all-the-women-go/|accessdate=13 September 2015}} *{{cite encyclopedia|first= Justine |last=Clark |first2=Paul |last2=Walker|title=Book, House, Home|encyclopedia=At Home in New Zealand|editor= Barbara Brooks |publisher=Bridget Williams Books}}<ref>{{Cite web|title = NZ domestic, Lois Daish|url = http://nzbooks.org.nz/1999/non-fiction/nz-domestic-lois-daish/|accessdate = 2015-09-13}}</ref>
== Selected exhibitions == ''1996 Cuttings from the Centre'', [[City Gallery Wellington|City Gallery]], Wellington. Co-curator and co-designer with Sharon Jansen.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Cuttings From the Centre|url = http://citygallery.org.nz/exhibitions/cuttings-centre|accessdate = 2015-09-13}}</ref>
2000 ''Looking for the Local'', an exhibition at the [[Adam Art Gallery]], [[Victoria University of Wellington]]. Co-designer and co-curator with Paul Walker.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Looking for the Local {{!}} Adam Art Gallery|url = http://www.adamartgallery.org.nz/past-exhibitions/looking-for-the-local/|website = www.adamartgallery.org.nz|accessdate = 2015-09-13}}</ref>
2015 ''Portraits of Practice,'' [http://sydney.edu.au/architecture/about/tinsheds/gallery/ Tin Sheds Gallery], [[University of Sydney]]. Co-curator and co-designer with Naomi Stead, Maryam Gusheh, Gill Matthewson and Fiona Young.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Portraits of Practice: At Work in Architecture|url = http://www.indesignlive.com/articles/parlour-inc-portraits-of-practice-at-work-in-architecture|accessdate = 2015-09-13}}</ref>
== Awards == Victorian Institute of Architects, Bates Smart Award for Architecture in the Media (2009) - for Architecture Australia's special issue on Indigenous Housing.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Justine Clark - Office of the Victorian Government Architect|url = http://www.ovga.vic.gov.au/victorian-design-review-panel/profile-page/15-profiles/26-justine-clark.html|website = www.ovga.vic.gov.au|accessdate = 2015-09-13|first = Kate|last = Mallyon|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151117021405/http://www.ovga.vic.gov.au/victorian-design-review-panel/profile-page/15-profiles/26-justine-clark.html|archivedate = 17 November 2015|df = dmy-all}}</ref>
Victorian Institute of Architects, Bates Smart Award for Architecture in the Media (2011) - for her contribution to architectural discourse through the architectural publication [http://architectureau.com/magazines/architecture-australia Architecture Australia]<ref>{{Cite web|title = Justine Clark - Office of the Victorian Government Architect|url = http://www.ovga.vic.gov.au/victorian-design-review-panel/profile-page/15-profiles/26-justine-clark.html|website = www.ovga.vic.gov.au|accessdate = 2015-09-13|first = Kate|last = Mallyon|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151117021405/http://www.ovga.vic.gov.au/victorian-design-review-panel/profile-page/15-profiles/26-justine-clark.html|archivedate = 17 November 2015|df = dmy-all}}</ref>
Victorian Institute of Architects, Bates Smart Award for Architecture in the Media (2013) - for her contribution to [http://archiparlour.org/about/ Parlour]<ref>{{Cite web|title = 2014 Bates Smart Award open|url = http://architectureau.com/articles/2014-bates-smart-award-for-architecture-in-the-media/|accessdate = 2015-09-13}}</ref>
Munro Diversity Award (2014), with Gill Matthewson.<ref>{{Cite web|url =http://www.architecturewomen.org.nz/aw%E2%80%A2nz-awards-2014|title =Architecture + Women NZ, Architecture Awards 2014.|date =|accessdate =|website =|publisher =|last =|first =|deadurl =yes|archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20151117101211/http://www.architecturewomen.org.nz/aw%E2%80%A2nz-awards-2014|archivedate =17 November 2015|df =dmy-all}}</ref>
Victorian Institute of Architects, Bates Smart Award for Architecture in the Media (2015) - for her contribution to the [http://archiparlour.org/parlour-guides/ Parlour Guides to Equitable Practice]<ref>{{Cite web|title = Parlour Equitable Practice Guidelines|url = http://architectureau.com/articles/equitable-practice-guidelines-for-comment/|accessdate = 2015-09-13}}</ref>

revision.text:
{{redirect|Hašler}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Karel Hašler | image = Karel Hašler-1904 foto Josef Fiedler.jpg | imagesize = 150px | caption = Karel Hašler in one of his roles at the National Theatre, Prague, around 1904. | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=y|1879|10|31}} | birth_place = [[Prague]], [[Kingdom of Bohemia]] | death_date = {{death date and age|df=y|1941|12|22|1879|10|31}} | death_place = [[Mauthausen-Gusen concentration camp|Mauthausen]], [[Nazi Germany]] | other_names = | occupation = Actor
songwriter
Film director
writer
dramatist
screenwriter | years_active = | spouse = | partner = | website = }} '''Karel Hašler''' (31 October 1879 in [[Prague]] – 22 December 1941 in [[Mauthausen-Gusen concentration camp|Mauthausen]]) was a [[Czech people|Czech]] songwriter, actor, lyricist, film and theatre director, composer, writer, dramatist, screenwriter and cabaretier. He was murdered in the Mauthausen concentration camp.{{cite web | title=Singer and songwriter Karel Hasler was born 125 years ago | url=http://www.radio.cz/en/article/58960 | work= | publisher=Radio Prague |author=Horáková, Pavla | date=8 October 2004 | accessdate=27 August 2009}} == Biography == Hašler studied to be a glove-maker, but he became intererested in theatre at a young age and occasionally performed with amateur theatre ensembles. In 1897, following his debut at the ''Aréna Theatre'' he left home and successively joined various travelling theatre companies.[[#Fikejz|Fikejz (2006)]], p. 367 In 1902 he became a member of the Slovenian theatre in [[Ljubljana]], but soon moved back to Prague, where he joined the [[National Theatre (Prague)|National Theatre]] ensemble. In the National Theatre, he asserted himself in conversational plays. In addition to that, he also attempted to apply his singing abilities. Around 1908, he started composing his own music, and at the same time he began to incline to cabaret activities. Gradually he became a director and head of various Prague cabarets, such as ''Lucerna'' (1910–1915, 1918–1923), ''Rokoko'' (1915–1918) and ''[[Karlín]] Variety Theatre'' (1924–1929). In 1908, he married a sister of pianist and composer [[Rudolf Friml]].{{cite web | title=Karel Hašler? Největší český hitmaker | url=http://zpravy.idnes.cz/mfdnes.asp?r=vikendV&v=255&c=1281519 | work= | publisher=iDnes.cz | author=Homolová, Marie | date=31 October 2009 | accessdate=2 November 2009}} ''(Jednou tak zabrousil do hospody, kde se potkal s Rudolfem Frimlem, a byla to chvíle osudová, nejen proto, že se oženil s Frimlovou sestrou Zdenou.)'' {{cs icon}}[[#Deyl|Deyl (2007)]], p. 202 During [[World War I]] he also began to appear in [[silent film]]s, as an actor, director and author. In 1914, he made a comedy ''České hrady a zámky'' (Czech Castles), based on his own script. The film was intended as an introduction for the play ''Pán bez kvartýru'' (A Man Without Flat). He appeared also in the comedy ''Ahasver'' and in other silent films. {| class="toccolours" style="float: left; margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em; font-size: 85%; background:#c6dbf7; color:black; width:18em; max-width: 25%;" cellspacing="5" | style="text-align: left;" | "If our songs perish, We'd lose all we cherish; Living would then be in vain." |- | style="text-align: left;" | ''Ta naše písnička česká'', end of the third stanza, English translation published in Chicago, 1934.{{cite web | title=Tom Hasler: Prodigal son's odyssey | url=http://www.praguepost.cz/archivescontent/38296-tom-hasler-prodigal-son-s-odyssey.html | work= | publisher=The Prague Post | date= |author=Levy, Alan | accessdate=8 November 2014}} |} Among his most successful film roles were the lawyer and deputy Uher in the drama film ''Batalion'' (The Battalion, 1927) by [[Přemysl Pražský]], and the organist in ''Varhaník u sv. Víta'' (Organist at [[St. Vitus Cathedral]], 1929) by [[Martin Frič]]. The coming era of the [[sound film]] in 1930s enabled Hašler to utilize his singing skills. In his first sound film role ''Písničkář'' (Balladeer, 1932) by [[Svatopluk Innemann]] he sang patriotic songs ''Svoboda'' (Freedom) and ''[[Ta naše písnička česká]]'' (Our Czech song), among others.[[#Fikejz|Fikejz (2006)]], p. 368 In 1942, in his last film role, he played himself in ''Za tichých nocí'' (In the Quiet Nights), made by his son Gina Hašler. From 1932 to 1941 Hašler played in more than 13 films. In September 1941, during production of the film ''Městečko na dlani'', based on the script by [[Jan Drda]], he was arrested by the [[Gestapo]] and sent to the Mauthausen [[concentration camp]]. The main reason for his arrest was his patriotic songs.{{cite web | title=Scény z prezidentské kuchyně" uvidí v Hradci Králové | url=http://www.rozhlas.cz/hradec/zpravy/_zprava/555132 | work= | publisher=Czech Radio – [[Hradec Králové]] | date= | accessdate=30 August 2009|language=cs}}[[#Deyl|Deyl (2007)]], p. 300–303 In Mauthausen he was tortured to death.{{cite web | title=Music Against the War | url=http://www.musicology.upol.cz/articles/against.html | work= | publisher=[[Palacký University, Olomouc]] | date= |author=Vičar, Jan | accessdate=28 August 2009}} In the post-war [[Communist Czechoslovakia]] he was officially ignored for political reasons, because many of his songs hailed [[Tomáš Masaryk]] and [[Czechoslovak Legion]]naires, and mocked [[interbellum]] communists."From Good King Wenceslas to the Good Soldier Švejk: A Dictionary of Czech Popular Culture", [https://books.google.com/books?id=6qlnrXT2yS0C&pg=PA54 p. 54] ==Remembrance== [[File:Thomas Hasler u sochy svého otce.jpg|thumb|200x200px|Thomas Hasler after inauguration of his father's sculpture "The Songster" by Czech sculptor Stanislav Hanzík
Prague, 30 October 2009]] [[File:Hašlerův pomník - odhalení 2.jpg|left|thumb|Prague celebrated the 130th anniversary of Karel Hašler unveiling of his monument on the Old Castle Steps below the Prague Castle, Oktober 31, 2009]] A popular Czech herbal-[[menthol]] [[hard candy]] was called ''{{Interlanguage link multi|Hašlerka |cs|3=Hašlerka}}'' after him.{{cite web | title=Karel Hašler is Alive Again! | url=http://czechmatediary.com/2009/07/29/karel-hasler-is-alive-again-karel-hasler-je-znovu-nazivu/ | work= | publisher=CzechMateDiary – blog | date= | accessdate=28 August 2009}} They have been known since early 1900s. Now the trademark is owned by [[Nestle]].[http://www.radio.cz/en/section/curraffrs/new-exhibition-charts-development-of-czech-trade-from-haslerky-to-tesco "New exhibition charts development of Czech trade from Haslerky to Tesco"] ''"Hašlerky"'' is a recognizable type of songs, written by Hašler and of similar character. Czech astronomer [[Lenka Kotková]] (née L. Šarounová) named asteroid [[37939 Hašler]] after him.{{cite web | url = http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=37939 | title = JPL Small-Body Database Browser | accessdate = 28 April 2008 | publisher = [[NASA]]}} In 2008, Czech directors Marek Jícha and Josef Lustig made a documentary ''Písničkář, který nezemřel'' (The Immortal Balladeer of Prague) describing the fate of Hašler's illegitimate son Thomas Hasler.{{cite web | title=The Immortal Balladeer of Prague | url=http://www.kviff.com/en/film-archive-detail/20082274-the-immortal-balladeer-of-prague/ | work= | publisher=[[Karlovy Vary International Film Festival]] | date= | accessdate=28 August 2009}} On the occasion of Hašler's 130th anniversary (2009) a monument by sculptor Stanislav Hanzík was unveiled at the {{Interlanguage link multi|Old Castle Steps|cs|3=Staré zámecké schody}}.[http://magazin.ceskenoviny.cz/zpravy/pri-odhalovani-pomniku-haslerovi-davy-lidi-ucpaly-zamecke-schody/405438 ''Při odhalování pomníku Hašlerovi davy lidí ucpaly zámecké schody''] – České noviny, 31. 10. 2009[http://www.ct24.cz/domaci/spolecnost/71172-praha-oslavila-130-vyroci-karla-haslera-odhalenim-pomniku/ ''Praha oslavila 130. výročí Karla Hašlera odhalením pomníku''] – ČT24, 31. 10. 2009 In 2013 the band [[Patrola Šlapeto]] recorded a CD and DVD with 23 Hašler's songs based on original recordings found in musical archives. While there have been plenty recordings of Hasler's songs, this was the first in 80 years recording of the original tunes.[http://www.tyden.cz/rubriky/kultura/hudba/patrola-slapeto-nahrala-zapomenute-haslerovy-slagry_283011.html#.Ut9XTPTTli1 "Patrola Šlapeto nahrála zapomenuté Hašlerovy šlágry"] {{Listen |pos = right |filename = Hoši od Zborova.ogg |title = "Hoši od Zborova" |description = Sample of instrumental "Hoši od Zborova" by Karel Hašler, dedicated to [[Czechoslovak Legion]] in the [[Battle of Zborov (1917)|Battle of Zborov]] }} Karel Hašlers artistic output consists mainly of songs. He created more than 300 compositions, many of which became popular "folk songs". With his engaged patriotic approach he helped to strengthen the national consciousness of Czech people during times of danger and oppression. Following his death in the concentration camp, his songs became a symbol of national resistance. ==Works== '''Selected songs''' * ''Hoši od Zborova'' * ''Kampak na nás, bolševíci?'' (1919) * ''[[Po starých zámeckých schodech]]'' * ''Pětatřicátníci'' * ''Ta naše písnička česká'' * ''Čí je Praha? Naše!'' * ''Já mám holku od Odkolků'' * ''Strahováček'' * ''Podskalák'' '''Actor:''' * ''Pantáta Bezoušek'' (The Old Man Bezousek, 1941) – Councillor Burdych * ''Roztomilý člověk'' (A Charming Man, 1941) – Editor-in-chief * ''[[In the Still of the Night (film)|In the Still of the Night]]'' (1941) – Karel Hašler * ''Jarní písnička'' (Spring Song, 1937) – Chodec * ''Vzdušné torpédo 48'' (Air Torpedo 48, 1936) – Dr Marvan * ''[[Long Live with Dearly Departed|Ať žije nebožtík]]'' (Long Live with Dearly Departed, 1935) – Petr Kornel * ''[[Jedenácté přikázání]]'' (The Eleventh Commandment, 1935) – The Police Captain * ''Král ulice'' (King of the Street, 1935) – Martin Antoni/Martin * ''Za ranních červánků'' (1934) – Josef Dobrovský * ''Srdce za písničku'' (A Heart for a Song, 1933) – Hugo Strindberg * ''Záhada modrého pokoje'' (Mystery of a Blue Room, 1933) – Count Hellford * ''Jindra, hraběnka Ostrovínová'' (Jindra, the Countess Ostrovín, 1933) – Musician Jahoda * ''Písničkář'' (Balladeer, 1932) – Pavel Hala * ''[[Do You Know That Little House on Lake Michigan?]]'' (1929) – Kennedy * ''Adjunkt Vrba'' (Adjunct Vrba, 1929) – Maran * ''[[The Organist at St. Vitus' Cathedral|Varhaník u sv. Víta]]'' (Organist at [[St. Vitus Cathedral]], 1929) – Organist * ''Batalion'' (Battalion, 1927) – JUDr. František Uher * ''[[Falešná kočička aneb Když si žena umíní|Falešná kočička]]'' (The Little False Cat, 1926) – MUDr. Karel Verner * ''Cikán Jura'' (Gypsy Jura, 1922) * ''Ahasver'' (1915) – Painter's Husband Valentin * ''České hrady a zámky'' (Czech Castles and Palaces, 1914) .... (1936) – screenplay * ''Vzdušné torpédo 48'' (Air Torpedo 48, 1936) * ''[[Jánošík (1935 film)|Jánošík]]'' (1935) * ''Král ulice'' (King of Street, 1935) – screenplay * ''Za ranních červánků'' (1934) – revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/178.95.32.160|178.95.32.160]] ([[User talk:178.95.32.160|talk]]) to last revision by Marianna251. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{Refimprove|date=December 2013}} '''''Synopsis''''', also known as the '''''Kievan Synopsis''''' ({{Lang-ru|Синопсис, албо Краткое описание о начале русскаго народа}}) is work of history, first published in [[Kiev]] in 1674. It interprets history through a [[Christian conception of time]] focused on the narratives of [[Genesis creation narrative|creation]], [[fall of man|fall]], and [[Redemption (theology)|redemption]].<ref>https://www.aatseel.org/100111/pdf/5a7_2_rikoun.pdf</ref> It also had a political purpose to justify the [[Treaty of Pereyaslav]] which annexed the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] to the [[Tsardom of Russia]] while also claiming a central role for the city of Kiev.
[[Innokentiy Gizel]] is generally considered to be the author of ''Synopsis'', however this is arguable. ''Synopsis'' was the first textbook on the subject of history written in any [[Slavic language]].{{fact|date=December 2017}} It was rather popular until the mid-19th century and survived some thirty editions.
The book began with the history of the origins and lifestyle of the [[Slavic people|Slavs]] and ended with the mid-17th century in the first edition. The second and third editions (1678 and 1680) end with the [[Chigirin Campaigns]] of 1677-1678. ''Synopsis'' covers the history of [[Kievan Rus']], the [[Mongol invasion of Rus']], and the struggles against the [[Crimean Khanate|Crimean Tatars]], [[Ottoman Turkey]], and [[Kingdom of Poland|Poland]]. The author of the ''Synopsis'' asserted that the Russian [[tsar]]s were the legal successors of the [[Kiev]]an [[grand prince]]s. ''Synopsis'' is notable since it clearly demonstrates that the idea of uniting all [[East Slavic people]] under the authority of one state was born not in [[Moscow]] but in the south-western lands of former [[Kievan Rus']] and designed in Kiev.{{Citation needed|date=July 2017}}
The purpose of the work is to "achieve a precarious balance between glorifying the Muscovite tsar on the one hand and defending Kiev’s own claims to power on the other."<ref>https://www.aatseel.org/100111/pdf/5a7_2_rikoun.pdf</ref>
The appendix of the ''Synopsis'' contains lists of Russian princes, [[Poland|Polish]] [[Voivode]]s in [[Little Russia]], [[Cossack]] [[hetman]]s, and Kievan [[metropolitan bishop|metropolitan]]s.

This is a list of [[Theater (structure)|theaters]] designated for the express purpose of presenting and producing dance performances. Dance venues such as these often have particular attributes including sprung floors and steeply raked seating areas. In addition, these spaces commonly convert into dance studios and are equipped with mirrors.
==United States==
*[[Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater|Ailey]] Citigroup Theater - New York City *[[Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet|Theater at Cedar Lake Contemporary Ballet]] - New York City *[[Cowles Center for Dance and the Performing Arts]] - Minneapolis, Minnesota *[[Dance Place]] - Washington, DC *[[Dance Theater Workshop]] - New York City *[[Danspace Project]] - New York City *[[Washington Ballet|England Studio Theater]] - Washington, DC *[[Harris Theater (Chicago)|Joan W. and Irving B. Harris Theater for Music and Dance]] - Chicago, Illinois *[[Jacob's Pillow]] - Becket, Massachusetts *[[Joyce Theater]] - New York City *[[Merce Cunningham]] Studio - New York City *[[New York Live Arts]] - New York City *[[Performance Garage]] - Philadelphia, Pennsylvania
==France== *[[Opéra de Paris]] *[[Opéra Bastille]] - Paris *[[Théâtre de la Ville]] - Paris
==England== *[[Trinity Laban|Laban Theatre]] - South East London *[[King's Hall, Herne Bay|The King's Hall]] - [[Herne Bay, Kent]]; auditorium doubles as dance area with sprung floor *[[The Place|The Place: Centre for Contemporary Dance]] - London
==Belgium== *[[La Monnaie]] - Brussels
{{Dance}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox artist | name = Louis-Frédéric Schützenberger | image = Louis Frédéric SCHÜTZENBERGER.jpg | imagesize = 140px | caption = Louis Schützenberger | birth_date = {{birth date|1825|9|08}} | birth_place = [[Strasbourg]], [[Bourbon Restoration|Kingdom of France]] | death_date = {{death date|1903|04|17}} | death_place = [[Strasbourg|Straßburg]], [[German Empire]] | nationality = French, German | field = Painter | training = {{Plainlist| * ''[[École nationale supérieure des Beaux-Arts]]'' * ''[[Paul Delaroche]]'' * ''[[Marc-Charles-Gabriel Gleyre]]'' }} | movement = [[Realist visual arts|Realism]] | awards = {{Unbulleted list<!--How about, other service medals which he should have qualified for?--> | {{Ribbon devices|number=0|type=oak|ribbon=Legion Honneur Chevalier ribbon.svg|width=60}} [[Legion of Honour]] – Chevalier }} }} '''Louis-Frédéric Schützenberger''' ([[Strasbourg]] September 8, 1825, [[Strasbourg]] April 17, 1903) was a German-French [[Painting|painter]].
== Biography == [[File:Louis Frédéric Schutzenberger - Portrait d'homme.jpg|thumb|''Portrait of a Man'' (1897), [[Musée des Beaux-Arts de Strasbourg]].]] Schützenberger was born in an [[Alsace|Alsatian]] family of famous brewers in Strasbourg. He was a student of [[Paul Delaroche]] and [[Marc-Charles-Gabriel Gleyre]] at [[École nationale supérieure des Beaux-Arts]]. Chevalier [[French Legion of Honor]] since 1870.
In a period between 1870 and 1885 he was the owner of the Scharrachbergheim-Irmstett castle, where he had made his studio on the first floor.
The artist [[René Schützenberger]] was his first cousin once removed.
== Works == {{Commons category|Louis Frédéric Schützenberger}} *''Chasseur sonnant du cor ou L'Hallali'', 1859, [[Musée des Beaux-Arts de Strasbourg|Museum of Fine Arts of Strasbourg]] *''Portrait d'homme'', [[Musée des Beaux-Arts de Strasbourg|Museum of Fine Arts of Strasbourg]] *''Terpsichore'', c. 1861, [[Paris]], [[Musée d'Orsay]] *''Centaures chassant le sanglier'', 1864, Paris, Musée d'Orsay *''L'Enlèvement d'europe'', 1865, huile sur toile, 146x223, [[Musée des beaux-arts d'Arras]] *''Portrait de Mélanie Schützenberger'', tante de l'artiste, 1865, [[Musée des Beaux-Arts de Strasbourg|Museum of Fine Arts of Strasbourg]] *''Portrait de Th. Berger'', [[Musée des Beaux-Arts de Strasbourg|Museum of Fine Arts of Strasbourg]] *''Entrevue de César et d'Arioviste en Alsace'', Musée des beaux-arts de [[Mulhouse]] *''Le Soir'', Musée des beaux arts de [[Mulhouse]] *''L'Exode (famille alsacienne quittant son pays)'', 1872, Musée des beaux arts de [[Mulhouse]] *''Portrait de Mme Parot'', 1875, [[Musée des Beaux-Arts de Strasbourg|Museum of Fine Arts of Strasbourg]] *''Portrait de Louis Schützenberger Père, brasseur à Schiltigheim'', 1876, [[Musée historique de Strasbourg]] *''Portrait de Mme Weber-Schlumberger'', 1881, [[Musée des Beaux-Arts de Strasbourg|Museum of Fine Arts of Strasbourg]] *''Portrait du baron Maximilien Frédéric Albert De Dietrich'', 1882, private collection *''Scène d'inquisition'', 1889, private collection *''Portrait d'homme'', 1897, [[Musée des Beaux-Arts de Strasbourg|Museum of Fine Arts of Strasbourg]] *''Portrait de femme'', 1900, private collection *''Portrait du gouverneur Louis-Gustave Binger'', 1900, [[Musée d'art et d'histoire Louis Senlecq]] *''Portrait de femme'', [[Musée des Beaux-Arts de Strasbourg|Museum of Fine Arts of Strasbourg]] *''Souvenir d'Italie - Fuite en Égypte'', Musée des beaux arts de [[Mulhouse]] *''Femme nue'', début du xxe siècle, [[Strasbourg Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art]]

Série 3 *[http://www.culture.fr/content/search?type=collections&SearchText=Louis+Fr%C3%A9d%C3%A9ric+Sch%C3%BCtzenberger&SearchButton=Rechercher Louis Frédéric Schützenberger - Culture.fr] *[http://www.iment.com/maida/family/mother/vicars/louisschutzenberger.htm Master Paintings of the World] *[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6429209x/f259.image.r=Ren%C3%A9%20Sch%C3%BCtzenberger.langFR L'Art en Alsace-Lorraine, par René Ménard, 1876, p.193] *[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6424086g/f76.image.r=Sch%C3%BCtzenberger%20Louis%20Fr%C3%A9d%C3%A9ric.langFR Notice des peintures, sculptures et dessins de l'École moderne, Musée National du Luxembourg, 1886.] *[http://www.culture.gouv.fr/public/mistral/mersri_fr?ACTION=CHERCHER&FIELD_1=REF&VALUE_1=IA67007019 Inventaire général du patrimoine culturel] *[[:fr:Schützenberger (famille)|Family genealogy Schützenberger]] *[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k64608366/f119.image.r=Ren%C3%A9%20Sch%C3%BCtzenberger.langFR Awards] *[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k5456053b/f15.image.r=Sch%C3%BCtzenberger.langEN ''Le Monde Artiste'', necrologue, 1903] *[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6438824n/f177.image.r=Sch%C3%BCtzenberger.langFR ''Guide dans l'exposition universelle de 1855''] *[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k6202645z.image.r=Louis+Sch%C3%BCtzenberger.f4.langEN ''Mention honorable au l'exposition universelle de 1900''] *[http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k5710357s/f84.image.r=Sch%C3%BCtzenberger.langEN ''Bacchante'', L.Schutzenberger]

revision.text:
{{Muhammad}}
During the [[Early Middle Ages]], [[Christendom]] largely viewed [[Islam]] as a [[list of Christian heresies|Christological heresy]] and [[Muhammad in Islam|Muhammad]] as a [[false prophet]]. By the [[Late Middle Ages]], Islam was more typically grouped with [[Paganism|heathenism]], and [[Muhammad]] was viewed as inspired by the [[Devil in Christianity|devil]]. A more relaxed or benign view of Islam only developed in the modern period, after the Islamic empires ceased to be an acute military threat to Europe. See [[Orientalism]].
The earliest documented Christian knowledge of Muhammad stems from [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine]] sources, written shortly after Muhammad's death in 632. With the [[Crusades]] of the [[High Middle Ages]], and the wars against the [[Ottoman Empire]] during the [[Late Middle Ages]], the Christian reception of Muhammad became more [[polemic]]al, moving from the classification as a heretic to depiction of Muhammad as a servant of [[Satan]] or as the [[Antichrist]], who will be suffering tortures in [[Christian views on hell|Hell]].
== Overview == {{Main|Criticism of Muhammad#Christian criticism|Muhammad in the Bible#Muhammad as Antichrist}} In contrast to the views of [[Muhammad in Islam]], the Christian image stayed highly negative for over a millennium.<ref name="Britannica">"Muhammad." Encyclopædia Britannica. 2007. Encyclopædia Britannica Online. 10 January 2007, [http://search.eb.com/eb/article-251806 eb.com article].</ref><ref>{{cite book | author=[[John Esposito|Esposito, John]] | year=1998 | title=Islam: The Straight Path | publisher=Oxford University Press | isbn=0-19-511233-4}} p.14</ref><ref>{{cite book | author=[[William Montgomery Watt|Watt, W. Montgomery]] | title=Muhammad: Prophet and Statesman | publisher=Oxford University Press | year=1974 | isbn=0-19-881078-4}} New Edition, p.231</ref>
=== Early Middle Ages === The earliest written Christian knowledge of Muhammad stems from [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine]] sources, written shortly after Muhammad's death in 632. In the anti-Jewish polemic the ''[[Teaching of Jacob]]'', a dialogue between a recent Christian convert and several [[Jews]], one participant writes that his brother "wrote to [him] saying that a deceiving prophet has appeared amidst the [[Saracen]]s". Another participant in the ''Doctrina'' replies about Muhammad: "He is deceiving. For do prophets come with sword and [[chariot]]?, …[Y]ou will discover nothing true from the said prophet except human bloodshed".<ref>Walter Emil Kaegi, Jr., "Initial Byzantine Reactions to the Arab Conquest", ''[[Church History (journal)|Church History]]'', Vol. 38, No. 2 (June , 1969), p. 139–149, p. 139–142, quoting from ''Doctrina Jacobi nuper baptizati'' 86–87</ref> Though Muhammad is never called by his name,<ref>''Mahomet'', among other [[Anglicisation|anglicized]] forms (such as [[Mahound]]), were popular for rendering of the Arabic name Muhammad, borne by the founder of the religion of Islam (died 633). In literary use now superseded by the more correct form Mohammed.</ref><ref>''[[New English Dictionary on Historical Principles]]'', Volume 6. By [[Philological Society|Philological Society (Great Britain)]]. Pg [https://books.google.com/books?id=iakjAQAAMAAJ&pg=RA1-PA38 38]</ref> there seems to have been knowledge of his existence. It also appears that both [[Judaism's views on Muhammad|Jews]] and Christians viewed him in a negative light.<ref>Kaegi p. 139–149, p. 139–142</ref> Other contemporary sources, such as the writings of [[Sophronius of Jerusalem]], show there was no knowledge of the Saracens having their own prophet or faith, and only remark that the Saracen attacks must be a punishment for Christian [[sin]]s.<ref>Kaegi p. 139–149, p. 139–141,</ref>
Knowledge of Muhammad was available in [[Christendom]] from after the early expansion of his religion<ref>[[Henry Stubbe]] ''An account of the rise and progress of Mahometanism'' Pg [https://books.google.com/books?id=ZG1AAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA211 211]</ref><ref>''The Oxford Companion to Christian Thought''. Edited by Adrian Hastings, Alistair Mason, Hugh Pyper. Pg 330.</ref> and, later, the translation of a polemical work by [[John of Damascus]], who used the phrase "[[false prophet]] in "Heresies in Epitome: How They Began and Whence They Drew Their Origin.".<ref>http://orthodoxinfo.com/general/stjohn_islam.aspx</ref><ref>Source: "The Fountain of Wisdom" (''pege gnoseos''), part II: "Concerning Heresy" (''peri aipeseon'')</ref> According to the ''[[Encyclopædia Britannica]]'' Christian knowledge of Muhammad's life "was nearly always used abusively".<ref name="Britannica"/> Another influential source was the [[Epistolae Saraceni]] or the “Letters of a Saracen” written by an Oriental Christian and translated into Latin from Arabic.<ref name="Britannica"/> From the 9th century onwards, highly negative biographies of Muhammad were written in Latin,<ref name="Britannica"/> such as the one by [[Álvaro of Córdoba (Mozarab)|Álvaro of Córdoba ]] proclaiming him the [[Antichrist]].<ref name="meyer2"/> Christendom also gained some knowledge of Muhammad through the [[Mozarabs]] of Spain, such as the 9th-century [[Eulogius of Córdoba]],<ref name="Britannica"/> who was one of the [[Martyrs of Córdoba]].
=== High Middle Ages === {{see|Vita Mahumeti}} [[File:Mohammed2.jpg|Mohammed and the Murdered Monk|thumb|left|250px|"Mohammed and the Murdered Monk", 1508 engraving by [[Lucas van Leyden]] – an incident unattested in Islamic accounts of the Prophet's life]] In the 11th century [[Petrus Alphonsi]], a Jew who converted to Christianity, was another Mozarab source of information on Muhammad.<ref name="Britannica"/> Later during the 12th century [[Peter the Venerable]], who saw Muhammad as the precursor to the Antichrist and the successor of [[Arius]],<ref name="meyer2"/> ordered the translation of the [[Quran]] into Latin (''[[Lex Mahumet pseudoprophete]]'') and the collection of information on Muhammad so that Islamic teachings could be refuted by Christian scholars.<ref name="Britannica"/>
During the 13th century European biographers completed their work on the life of Muhammad in a series of works by scholars such as [[Peter Pascual]], [[Riccoldo da Monte di Croce]], and [[Ramon Llull]]<ref name="Britannica"/> in which Muhammad was depicted as an Antichrist while [[Islam]] was shown to be a Christian [[heresy]].<ref name="Britannica"/> The fact that Muhammad was unlettered, that he married a wealthy widow, that in his later life he had several wives, that he was involved in several wars, and that he died like an ordinary person in contrast to the Christian belief in the supernatural end of [[Jesus]]' earthly life were all arguments used to discredit Muhammad.<ref name="Britannica"/>
Medieval scholars and churchmen held that Islam was the work of Muhammad who in turn was inspired by Satan. [[Kenneth Setton]] wrote that Muhammad was frequently calumniated and made a subject of legends taught by preachers as fact.<ref name="meyer1">Kenneth Meyer Setton (July 1, 1992). "[https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN0871692015&id=hk4LAAAAIAAJ&printsec=titlepage Western Hostility to Islam and Prophecies of Turkish Doom]". Diane Publishing. {{ISBN|0-87169-201-5}}. pg 1–5</ref> For example, in order to show that Muhammad was the anti-Christ, it was asserted that Muhammad died not in the year 632 but in the year 666 – the [[number of the beast]] – in another variation on the theme the number "666" was also used to represent the period of time Muslims would hold sway of the land.<ref name="meyer2"/> A verbal expression of Christian contempt for Islam was expressed in turning his name from Muhammad to [[Mahound]], the "devil incarnate".<ref>{{cite book | author=Reeves, Minou | title=Muhammad in Europe: A Thousand Years of Western Myth-Making | year=2003 | publisher=NYU Press | isbn=978-0-8147-7564-6}}, p.3</ref> Others usually confirmed to pious Christians that Muhammad had come to a bad end.<ref name="meyer1"/> According to one version after falling into a drunken stupor he had been eaten by a herd of swine, and this was ascribed as the reason why Muslims proscribed consumption of alcohol and pork.<ref name="meyer1"/> In another account of the alcohol ban, Muhammad learns about the Bible from a Jew and a heretical [[Arianism|Arian]] monk. Muhammad and the monk get drunk and fall asleep. The Jew kills the monk with Muhammad's sword. He then blames Muhammad, who, believing he has committed the crime in a drunken rage, bans alcohol.<ref>Bushkovich, Paul, "Orthodoxy and Islam in Russia", Steindorff, L. (ed) ''Religion und Integration im Moskauer Russland: Konzepte und Praktiken, Potentiale und Grenzen 14.-17. Jahrhundert'', Otto Harrassowitz Verlag, 2010, p.128.</ref>
''Leggenda di Maometto'' is another example of such a story. In this version, as a child Muhammad was taught the black arts by a heretical Christian villain who escaped imprisonment by the [[Christian Church]] by fleeing to the [[Arabian Peninsula]]; as an adult he set up a false religion by selectively choosing and perverting texts from the [[Bible]] to create Islam. It also ascribed the Muslim holiday of Friday "dies Veneris" (day of [[Venus (mythology)|Venus]]), as against the Jewish (Saturday) and the Christian (Sunday), to his followers' depravity as reflected in their multiplicity of wives.<ref name="meyer1"/> A highly negative depiction of Muhammad as a heretic, false prophet, renegade cardinal or founder of a violent religion also found its way into many other works of European literature, such as the [[chansons de geste]], [[William Langland]]'s ''[[Piers Plowman]]'', and [[John Lydgate]]'s ''The Fall of the Princes''.<ref name="Britannica"/> [[File:Dante and Virgil Meet Muhammad and His Son-in-law, Ali in Hell.jpg|thumb|right|Muhammad pulling his chest open in [[William Blake]]'s illustration of [[Dante Alighieri]]'s "[[Divine Comedy]]"]]
The thirteenth century ''[[Golden Legend]]'', a best-seller in its day containing a collection of hagiographies, describes "Magumeth (Mahomet, Muhammad)" as "a false prophet and sorcerer", detailing his early life and travels as a merchant through his marriage to the widow, Khadija and goes on to suggest his "visions" came as a result of epileptic seizures and the interventions of a renegade [[Nestorianism|Nestorian]] monk named Sergius.<ref>https://books.google.com/books?id=GNWZgIL5ZCoC&pg=PA753&source=gbs_toc_r&cad=3#v=onepage&q&f=false</ref>
====The Divine Comedy==== In [[Dante Alighieri]]'s ''[[Divine Comedy]]'', Muhammad is in the ninth ditch of [[Malebolge]], the eighth realm, designed for those who have caused schism; specifically, he was placed among the Sowers of Religious Discord. Muhammad is portrayed as split in half, with his entrails hanging out, representing his status as a [[heresiarch]] (Canto 28): :No barrel, not even one where the hoops and staves go every which way, was ever split open like one frayed Sinner I saw, ripped from chin to where we fart<!-- this is the actual quotation; do not remove--> below. :His guts hung between his legs and displayed His vital organs, including that wretched sack Which converts to shit<!-- this is the actual quotation; do not remove --> whatever gets conveyed down the gullet. :As I stared at him he looked back And with his hands pulled his chest open, Saying, ''"See how I split open the crack in myself! See how twisted and broken Mohammed is! Before me walks [[Ali]], his face Cleft from chin to crown, grief–stricken."''<ref>{{cite book|author=Seth Zimmerman|title=The Inferno of Dante Alighieri |page=191 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r3hWDEjN7JcC&pg=PA191#v=onepage&q&f=false |year=2003 |publisher=iUniverse |isbn=0-595-28090-0}}</ref>
[[File:Mohameddemons2.jpg|thumb|right|Mohammed tortured in Hell from fresco in [[San Petronio Basilica]]]] This scene is frequently shown in illustrations of the ''Divine Comedy''. Muhammad is represented in a 15th-century [[fresco]] ''[[Last Judgment]]'' by Giovanni da Modena and drawing on Dante, in the [[San Petronio Basilica]] in [[Bologna]],<ref name=fresco>{{cite web|url=http://arts.guardian.co.uk/news/story/0,11711,742914,00.html|title=Al-Qaida plot to blow up Bologna church fresco|date=2002-06-24|work=[[The Guardian]]|author=Philip Willan}}</ref> as well as in artwork by [[Salvador Dalí]], [[Auguste Rodin]], [[William Blake]], and [[Gustave Doré]].<ref name=Chronicle>{{cite web|url=http://sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/c/a/2006/02/11/MNGRCH6UQK1.DTL|title=What's behind Muslim cartoon outrage|date=2006-02-11|work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|author=Ayesha Akram}}</ref>
One common allegation laid against Muhammad was that he was an impostor who, in order to satisfy his ambition and his lust, propagated religious teachings that he knew to be false.<ref name="Watt">Watt, Montgomery, ''Muhammad: Prophet and Statesman.'' Oxford University Press, 1961. From p. 229.</ref> [[Cultural critic]] and author [[Edward Said]] wrote in ''[[Orientalism (book)|Orientalism]]'' regarding Dante's depiction of Muhammad: {{quote|Empirical data about the Orient […] count for very little [i.e., in Dante's work]; what matters and is decisive is […] by no means confined to the professional scholar, but rather the common possession of all who have thought about the Orient in the West […]. What […] Dante tried to do in the ''[[Inferno (Dante)|Inferno]]'', is […] to characterize the Orient as alien and to incorporate it schematically on a theatrical stage whose audience, manager, and actors are […] only for Europe. Hence the vacillation between the familiar and the alien; Mohammed is always the imposter (familiar, because he pretends to be like the Jesus we know) and always the Oriental (alien, because although he is in some ways "like" Jesus, he is after all not like him).<ref>{{cite book|last=Said|first=Edward|authorlink=Edward Said|title=Orientalism|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zvJ3YwOkZAYC|year=1979|publisher=Vintage Books|isbn=978-0-394-74067-6|page=68}}</ref>}} A more positive interpretation appears in the 13th-century ''Estoire del Saint Grail'', the first book in the vast [[Matter of Britain]], the [[Lancelot-Grail]]. In describing the travels of [[Joseph of Arimathea]], keeper of the [[Holy Grail]], the author says that most residents of the Middle East were pagans until the coming of Muhammad, who is shown as a true [[prophet]] sent by God to bring Christianity to the region. This mission however failed when Muhammad's pride caused him to alter God's wishes, thereby deceiving his followers. Nevertheless, Muhammad's religion is portrayed as being greatly superior to paganism.<ref>Lacy, Norris J. (Ed.) (December 1, 1992). ''Lancelot-Grail: The Old French Arthurian Vulgate and Post-Vulgate in Translation,'' Volume 1 of 5. New York: Garland. {{ISBN|0-8240-7733-4}}.</ref>
====Later presentations==== The depiction of Islam in the ''Travels of Sir [[John Mandeville]]'' is also relatively positive, though with many inaccurate and mythical features. It is said that Muslims are easily converted to Christianity because their beliefs are already so similar in many ways, and that they believe that only the Christian revelation will last until the end of the world. The moral behaviour of Muslims at the time is shown as superior to that of Christians, and as a standing reproach to Christian society.<ref name="travel">[http://www.romanization.com/books/mandeville/chap15.html The Travels of Sir John Mandeville], CHAPTER XV.</ref>
Depictions of Muhammad in the form of [[picaresque novel]] began to appear from the 13th century onward, such as in Alexandre du Pont's ''Roman de Mahom'', the translation of the Mi'raj, the ''Escala de Mahoma'' (“The Ladder of Muhammad”) by the court physician of Alfonso X of Castile and León and his son.<ref name="Britannica"/>
Medieval European literature often referred to Muslims as "[[infidel]]s" or "pagans", in sobriquets such as the ''paynim foe''. These depictions such as those in ''[[The Song of Roland]]'' represent Muslims worshiping Muhammad (spelt e.g. 'Mahom' and 'Mahumet') as a god, and depict them worshiping various deities in the form of "[[cult image|idols]]", ranging from [[Abaddon|Apollyon]] to [[Lucifer]], but ascribing to them a chief deity known as "[[Termagant]]".<ref name="meyer2">Kenneth Meyer Setton (July 1, 1992). "[https://books.google.com/books?vid=ISBN0871692015&id=hk4LAAAAIAAJ&printsec=titlepage Western Hostility to Islam and Prophecies of Turkish Doom]". Diane Publishing. {{ISBN|0-87169-201-5}}. pg 4-15</ref><ref>''[[Brewer's Dictionary of Phrase and Fable]]'', "[http://www.bartleby.com/81/16352.html Termagant]</ref>
Conversely, in medieval romances such as the French Arthurian cycle, pagans such as the ancient Britons or the inhabitants of "Sarras" before the conversion of King Evelake, who presumably lived well before the birth of Muhammad, are often described as worshipping the same array of gods and as identical to the imagined (Termagant-worshipping) Muslims in every respect. In the same vein, the definition of "[[Saracen]]" in [[Raymond of Penyafort]]'s ''Summa de Poenitentia'' starts by describing the Muslims but ends by including every person who is neither a Christian nor a Jew.
When the [[Knights Templar]] were being tried for [[heresy]] reference was often made to their worship of a demon [[Baphomet]], which was notable by implication for its similarity to the common rendition of Muhammad's name used by Christian writers of the time, Mahomet.<ref>''Mahomet'' still is the Polish and French word for the English "Muhammad".</ref> All these and other variations on the theme were all set in the "temper of the times" of what was seen as a Muslim-Christian conflict as Medieval Europe was building a concept of "the great enemy" in the wake of the quickfire success of the [[early Muslim conquests]] shortly after the fall of the [[Western Roman Empire]], as well as the lack of real information in the West of the mysterious East.<ref name="Watt"/>
Muhammad is characterized as "''pseudo-prophet''" in Byzantine and post-Byzantine religious and historic texts, as for example by [[Niketas Choniates]] (12th-13th c.).<ref name="Mai1840">{{cite book|last=Mai|first=Angelo|authorlink=Angelo Mai|title=Spicilegium romanum ...: Patrum ecclesiasticorum Serapionis, Ioh. Chrysostomi, Cyrilli Alex., Theodori Mopsuesteni, Procli, Diadochi, Sophronii, Ioh. Monachi, Paulini, Claudii, Petri Damiani scripta varia. Item ex Nicetae Thesauro excerpta, biographi sacri veteres, et Asclepiodoti militare fragmentum|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R-oXAAAAYAAJ|year=1840|publisher=typis Collegii urbani|page=304}}</ref>
== See also == {{Wikipedia books |1=Criticism of Islam }} {{commons|محمد_بن_عبد_الله#Western_depictions|Medieval depictions of Muhammad}} {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| *[[Baphomet]] *[[Christianity and Islam]] *[[Jesus in Islam]] *[[Mahound]] *[[Mohammedan]] *[[Muhammad in the Bible]] *[[Orientalism]] *[[Saracen]] *[[Termagant]] }}

Constructing the Image of Muhammad in Europe. Perceptions and Misperceptions''] * [[Washington Irving|Irving, W.]] (1868). [https://books.google.com/books?id=4k0LAAAAIAAJ Mahomet and his successors]. New York: Putnam {{refend}}

Noth, Trude Ehlert | encyclopedia=[[Encyclopedia of Islam]] Online | title=Various articles | publisher=Brill Academic Publishers | issn=1573-3912}} *{{cite encyclopedia | encyclopedia=The New Encyclopædia Britannica | publisher=Encyclopædia Britannica, Incorporated; Rev Ed edition | year=2005 | ISBN=978-1-59339-236-9}} {{refend}}
[[Category:Religious perspectives on Muhammad]] [[Category:Criticism of Islam]] [[Category:Christianity in the Middle Ages]] [[Category:Christianity and Islam]] [[Category:Point of view]]

{{no footnotes|date=March 2018}} {{for|the American comic strip '''Mixed Media'''|Jack Ohman}} [[File:Alberto_Baumann_Eredità_del_ventesimo_secolo_1980_cm_100x100.jpg|thumb|right|180px|Alberto Baumann, "Inheritance of the Twentieth Century" (1980).]] [[File:SOMETIME_LAST_JANUARY_I_AWOKE_IN_THE_MORNING_WITH_MY_HAND_UP,_2005_mixed_media.jpeg|thumb|right|180px|Mixed media art by [[Adam Niklewicz]].]]
In [[visual art]], '''mixed media''' is an [[work of art|artwork]] in which more than one [[Art medium|medium]] or material has been employed. Assemblages and collages are two common examples of art using different medias that will make use of different materials including [[cloth]], [[paper]], and/or [[wood]]. <ref name="assemblages and collages"> [https://keeleybassett.wordpress.com/2016/11/16/what-is-the-difference-between-collage-montage-and-assemblage/]</ref>
When an artist is doing painting or photography work using mixed media, care should be taken to allow enough drying time between layers, to ensure the final work will have structural integrity. If several different mixed medias are used with the artwork, it is important to choose a sturdy foundation upon which the different media layers are imposed.
Many artistic effects can be achieved by using mixed media. [[Found objects]] can be used in conjunction with traditional artist media to attain a wide range of self-expression.
Some children's picture books also use mixed media illustrations. For example, [['s Nachts]] by [[Wolf Erlbruch]].
Mixed media art, a visual art, is distinguished from [[Multimedia|multimedia art]] which combines visual art with non-visual elements, such as recorded sound, literature, drama, dance, motion graphics, music, or interactivity.
==See also== *[[Altered book]] *[[Artist trading cards]] *[[Assemblage (art)]] *[[Collage]] *[[Décollage]] *[[Intermedia]] *[[List of mixed media artists]] *[[Modular art]] *[[Multimedia]] *[[New media art]] *[[Quilt art]] *[[Visual Focus Depth Art]]
== References == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20121106034519/http://www.kriegartstudio.com/nesting_cranes/susan_krieg_describes.htm ''Description of Mixed-Media Collage Creation''], by [[Susan Krieg]] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20121103132135/http://www.kriegartstudio.com/nesting_cranes/susan_krieg_history_collage.htm ''History of Collage''], Excerpts from Nita Leland and Virginia Lee and from George F. Brommer * [http://www.worldcatlibraries.org/oclc/31776510&referer=brief_results Open WorldCat pilot], Wright, Michael; Royal Academy of Arts ([[Great Britain]]): ''An introduction to mixed media'' ([[London]]; [[New York City|New York]]: Dorling Kindersley in association with the [[Royal Academy of Art]]s; [[Boston]]: Distributed by [[Houghton Mifflin]], 1995); {{ISBN|0-7894-0000-6}}; {{ISBN|0-7513-0748-3}}; [[OCLC]] 31776510. {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | image = http://www.publishersweekly.com/images/data/ARTICLE_PHOTO/photo/000/039/39401-1.JPG |type = Non-profit |headquarters = New York City, USA |services = Celebrating literary achievements |key_people = Lisa Lucas, Executive Director (March 2016) |name = National Book Foundation |founded = 1989 |fields = Literary Prize |homepage = {{URL|nationalbook.org}} | staff = 7 staff, 21 board members }}
The '''National Book Foundation''' (NBF) is an American [[nonprofit organization]] established "to raise the cultural appreciation of great writing in America". <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/09/11/magazine/lisa-lucas-wants-to-make-reading-fun-again.html|title=Lisa Lucas Wants to Make Reading Fun Again|author=|date=7 September 2016|publisher=|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref> Established 1989 by National Book Awards, Inc.,<ref name=nyt1989>Edwin McDowell. "Book Notes: 'The Joy Luck Club' is to be in paperback ... The National Book Awards' new foundation". ''The New York Times'', July 5, 1989, page C19.</ref> the foundation is the administrator and sponsor of the [[National Book Award]]s, a changing set of [[literary awards]] inaugurated 1936 and continuous from 1950. It also organizes and sponsors public and educational programs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/books/features/la-ca-jc-lisa-lucas-20160509-snap-story.html|title=Lisa Lucas, head of the National Book Foundation, wants you to love reading|first=Carolyn|last=Kellogg|date=|website=latimes.com}}</ref>
The National Book Foundation's Board of Directors comprises representatives of American literary institutions and the book industry. For example, in 2009 the Board included the President of the [[New York Public Library]], the Chief Merchandising Officer of [[Barnes & Noble]], the President/Publisher of [[Grove/Atlantic, Inc.]], and others.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.publishersweekly.com/pw/by-topic/industry-news/publisher-news/article/70585-national-book-foundation-names-two-new-board-members.html|title=National Book Foundation Names Two New Board Members|author=|date=|website=publishersweekly.com}}</ref> In 2016, Lisa Lucas became the Foundation's third Executive Director.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2016/02/10/lisa-lucas-named-executive-director-of-national-book-foundation/?_r=0|title=Lisa Lucas Named Executive Director of National Book Foundation|last=Williams|first=John|website=ArtsBeat|access-date=2016-05-17}}</ref>
The National Book Foundation states the mission "to celebrate the best of American literature, to expand its audience, and to enhance the cultural value of great writing in America."
==Awards== The original task of the National Book Foundation was to award the National Book Award. The Award was given without the foundation from 1950 until it was replaced with The American Book Awards in 1980, with 16 different categories. In 1987, the National Book Award was reestablished. The award split into 4 categories in 1996: Fiction, Nonfiction, Poetry, and Young People's Literature. The winner in each category is decided by an independent panel of writers, librarians, booksellers, and critics.<ref>Lynn Neary. [https://www.npr.org/2013/09/16/223132417/national-book-awards-look-to-raise-profile-and-its-not-the-first-time "National Book Awards Look to Raise Profile"]. ''NPR books''. September 16, 2013. [[National Public Radio]].</ref>
In addition to four National Book Awards to authors for particular books, the Foundation presents two lifetime achievement awards: the [[National Book Award#Medal for Distinguished Contribution (lifetime)|Medal for Distinguished Contribution to American Letters]] and the [[National Book Award#Literarian Award for Outstanding Service (lifetime)|Literarian Award for Outstanding Service to the American Literary Community]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://michaelcavacini.com/2015/11/19/james-patterson-honored-at-national-book-awards/|title=James Patterson Honored At National Book Awards|date=2015-11-19|website=Michael Cavacini|access-date=2016-05-17}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bigstory.ap.org/article/44096ee4eb0b419cb1859594e6d3cd5c/robert-caro-receive-honorary-national-book-award-medal|title=Robert Caro to receive honorary National Book Award medal|author=|date=|website=ap.org}}</ref>
The Foundation annually awards the [[Innovations in Reading Prize]] ($10,000) to "individuals and institutions—or partnerships between the two—that have developed innovative means of creating and sustaining a lifelong love of reading."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/jenniferbaker/2016/02/14/national-book-foundation-celebrates-innovators-of-reading/#55bb11a37e30|title=National Book Foundation Celebrates Innovators Of Reading Encouraging Philanthropy For More Literacy|last=Baker|first=Jennifer|website=Forbes|access-date=2016-05-17}}</ref>
==Programs==
===Book Up=== Book Up is an after school program for middle school students to foster a lifelong love of reading. The program is designed in a way meant to show kids how enjoyable reading can be, and to improve their confidence in their reading abilities. Middle School students are chosen as studies have shown that this is the age that students are the most likely to stop reading.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://electricliterature.com/infographic-national-book-foundations-bookup-helps-foster-a-lifelong-love-of-reading-f2b330bf0842|title=INFOGRAPHIC: National Book Foundation’s BookUp Helps Foster a Lifelong Love of Reading|author=|date=17 March 2015|website=electricliterature.com}}</ref>
The Program is typically run by authors with experience in teaching. Sessions last for at least 24 weeks, over which students share their reading interests and previous experiences with reading. Since BookUp began, the program has given out more than 30,000 free books to students. The program started in 2007 in New York City and has expanded to Hunstville, TX, Detroit, MI, and created BookUp LGBTQ for LGBTQ youth.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lambdaliterary.org/features/news/01/30/bookup-lgbtq-launches-at-the-hetrick-martin-institute/|title=BookUp LGBTQ Launches at the Hetrick-Martin Institute|date=2016-01-30|website=Lambda Literary|language=en-US|access-date=2016-05-17}}</ref>
===5 Under 35=== The 5 Under 35 program was started in 2005 in order to honor 5 young writers, all under the age of 35. The winners are all chosen by previous Finalists of the National Book Award. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/books/jacketcopy/la-ca-jc-5-under-35-20160908-snap-story.html|title=Meet the National Book Foundation's 5 Under 35|first=Michael|last=Schaub|date=|website=latimes.com}}</ref>In 2015, the winners were chosen by previous 5 Under 35 honorees. Each award comes with a cash prize of $1,000.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/jarrylee/5-under-35|title=Here Are The 2015 National Book Foundation 5 Under 35 Honorees|website=BuzzFeed|access-date=2016-05-17}}</ref> The 5 Under 35 Ceremony has been hosted by [[Questlove]], [[Carrie Brownstein]], [[LeVar Burton]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://flavorwire.com/540285/national-book-foundation-reveals-their-5-under-35-honorees|title=The National Book Foundation Reveals Its "5 Under 35" Honorees|date=2015-09-30|website=Flavorwire|language=en-US|access-date=2016-05-17}}</ref> and others.
=== Teen Press Conference === The Teen Press Conference invites middle and high school students in New York City to interview the five Young People's Literature Finalists the day before the National Book Awards. Students are provided copies of the Finalists' books. In 2015, the Teen Press Conference took place at the [[92nd Street Y]] with host [[Jacqueline Woodson]], a National Book Award Winner, as well as in Miami as part of the Miami Book Festival.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://miamibookfair.com/event/national-book-foundation-presents-the-teen-press-conference/|title=Upcoming Events – National Book Foundation presents the Teen Press Conference – Miami Book Fair|website=miamibookfair.com|access-date=2016-05-17}}</ref>
=== National Book Awards on Campus === National Book Awards on Campus is a program that brings National Book Award winners and finalists to college campuses. In 2015, for its 11th season, NBA on Campus took place at [[Sam Houston State University]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shsu.edu/academics/english/creative-writing/national-book-awards/|title=National Book Awards Festival|first=Sam Houston State|last=University|date=|website=SHSU Online}}</ref> [[Concordia College (Moorhead, Minnesota)|Concordia College]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.concordiacollege.edu/academics/events/national-book-awards-at-concordia/nba-history/|title=NBA History|author=|date=|website=Concordia College}}</ref> [[Amherst College]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amherst.edu/arts/the-common/national-book-awards-week|title=The Common Literary Magazine - National Book Awards on Campus - Amherst College|author=|date=|website=www.amherst.edu}}</ref> and [[Rollins College]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://360.rollins.edu/arts-and-culture/rollins-college-partners-with-the-national-book-awards|title=Rollins College Partners with the National Book Awards - Arts & Culture - Rollins College 360 News|author=|date=|website=360.rollins.edu}}</ref>
=== Eat, Drink & Be Literary === Eat, Drink & Be Literary is the National Book Foundation's partnership with [[Brooklyn Academy of Music|BAM]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bam.org/programs/2016/eat-drink-and-be-literary|title=Eat, Drink & Be Literary 2016|website=BAM.org|access-date=2016-05-17}}</ref> to create an intimate evening of food and literary conversation.
==See also== * [[National Book Award]] * [[Innovations in Reading Prize]]
==References== {{reflist |25em }}
;Citations * National Book Foundation. ''nationalbook.org''. : [http://nationalbook.org National Book Foundation: Presenter of the National Book Awards]. This home page retrieved 2014-12-06 carries the internal title "2014 National Book Award Winners".
==External links== * {{official website}}

{{italic title}} {{Expand French|Neptune (marbre)|date=July 2018}} [[File:Neptune_-_Pajou-Augustin_(droit).jpg|thumb]] '''''Neptune''''', '''''Neptune Calming the Waves''''' or '''''Irritated Neptune''''' is a 1767 marble sculpture of [[Neptune (mythology)|Neptune]] by the French artist [[Augustin Pajou]], now in the [[Museum of Fine Arts of Lyon]]. He produced a terracotta modello for the work.
